SMART Indicator Report: Coastal Water Quality 1 Indicator category Habitat, nearshore water quality 2 Indicator name Coastal Water Quality Includes variable(s): ALL 3 Indicator brief description Snapshot of coastal water bodies condition relative to water quality standards from EPA ATTAINS (Assessment, Total maximum daily load, Tracking And ImplementatioN System) as reported in the Mid Atlantic Ocean Data Portal (MARCO) 4 Indicator visualization More Mid-Atlantic waterways are unassessed or polluted than good in the current snapshot. EPA Waterway Assessments as of August 2025 5 Indicator documentation 5.1 Are indicators available for others to use (data downloadable)? Yes 5.1.1 Where can indicators be found? Unknown. 6 Comments 6.1 Additional potential links to management in addition to uses listed above This information could be used to inform the Council about estuarine and nearshore habitat status more dynamically and at a more refined spatial scale than the indicator in the current EAFM risk assessment. Source data appear to lag by several years but this is still more up to date than the 2009 coastal condition report. 6.2 What additional work would be needed for the Council to use the indicator? Work would be required to aggregate the waterway specific information to an indicator at larger spatial scales relevant to Council management. Some waterways may be more important to some species than others. Work would also be required to evaluate whether habitat status has changed over time, by comparing reports from different years. 6.3 What issues are caused if there is a gap or delay in data underlying the indicator If used in the EAFM risk assessment, risk rankings could be out of date. However, the currently used indicator is from a 2009 coastal condition report.
